sourceClass: Medical Disorders and Diseases, Public Health
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Disease
Prevention Daily \-- Researchers detail new data in type 2 diabetes. According
to news originating from Sari, Iran, by NewsRx correspondents, research
stated, "Dyslipidemia is one of the main risk factors of cardiovascular
disease in people with diabetes. The principle of diabetes prevention and
control is based on patient self-care and education."

Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Mazandaran
University of Medical Sciences: "The Islamic self-care nutrition method is a
common and successful way to modify behavior in Islamic ethics and mysticism.
The study aimed to determine the effect of the Islamic self-care nutrition
method on the lipid profile of patients with type 2 diabetes. The present
clinical trial was conducted in 2014 on 98 middle-aged patients with type 2
diabetes referred to the Diabetes Center of the Mazandaran University of
Medical Sciences, Sari, Iran, who were randomly allocated into two groups of
experimental and control. Lipid indices were measured before intervention, and
the same education about diabetic healthy diet was provided in both groups. In
addition, in the experimental group, Islamic teachings and the Islamic self-
care method of nutrition were taught with the intention of pleasing God. Data
were analyzed with SPSS 22 software using independent and paired t-test, Chi-
square, Fisher's exact, and analysis of covariance (ANCOVA). After adjusting
for the effect of confounding variables with ANCOVA, significant improvement
was observed in triglycerides and low-density lipoprotein indices in the
experimental group after intervention compared to the control group. Two-
proportion z-test results showed a significant increase in the use of lipid-
lowering drugs in the control group compared with the experimental group after
intervention."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The Islamic self-care
nutrition method could be used to control chronic diseases such as type 2
diabetes affected by behavioral factors."

For more information on this research see: Effect of the Islamic Self-care
Nutrition Method on the Lipid Profile of Patients with Type 2 Diabetes: A
Randomized Clinical Controlled Trial. _Open Access Macedonian Journal of
Medical Sciences_ , 2020,8(B). (Open Access Macedonian Journal of Medical
Sciences \- <http://www.id-press.eu/mjms/>). The publisher for Open Access
Macedonian Journal of Medical Sciences is ID Design 2012/DOOEL Skopje.

A free version of this journal article is available at
<https://doi.org/10.3889/oamjms.2020.4217>.

Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by
contacting Manizheh Zakizad Abkenar, Department of Community Health Nursing,
Nasibeh School of Nursing and Midwifery, Mazandaran University of Medical
Sciences, Sari, Iran. Additional authors for this research include Fazlollah
Ghofranipour, Zahra Kashi, Ali Montazeri.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Studies in the Area of Type 2 Diabetes Reported from Mazandaran University of Medical Sciences (Effect of the Islamic Self-care Nutrition Method on the Lipid Profile of Patients with Type 2 Diabetes: A Randomized Clinical Controlled Trial): Nutritional and Metabolic Diseases and Conditions - Type 2 Diabetes
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Disease Prevention Daily -- Researchers detail new data in type 2 diabetes. According to news originating from Sari, Iran, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “Dyslipidemia is one of the main risk factors of cardiovascular disease in people with diabetes. The principle of diabetes prevention and control is based on patient self-care and education.”

Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Mazandaran University of Medical Sciences: “The Islamic self-care nutrition method is a common and successful way to modify behavior in Islamic ethics and mysticism. The study aimed to determine the effect of the Islamic self-care nutrition method on the lipid profile of patients with type 2 diabetes. The present clinical trial was conducted in 2014 on 98 middle-aged patients with type 2 diabetes referred to the Diabetes Center of the Mazandaran University of Medical Sciences, Sari, Iran, who were randomly allocated into two groups of experimental and control. Lipid indices were measured before intervention, and the same education about diabetic healthy diet was provided in both groups. In addition, in the experimental group, Islamic teachings and the Islamic self-care method of nutrition were taught with the intention of pleasing God. Data were analyzed with SPSS 22 software using independent and paired t-test, Chi-square, Fisher’s exact, and analysis of covariance (ANCOVA). After adjusting for the effect of confounding variables with ANCOVA, significant improvement was observed in triglycerides and low-density lipoprotein indices in the experimental group after intervention compared to the control group. Two-proportion z-test results showed a significant increase in the use of lipid-lowering drugs in the control group compared with the experimental group after intervention.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “The Islamic self-care nutrition method could be used to control chronic diseases such as type 2 diabetes affected by behavioral factors.”

For more information on this research see: Effect of the Islamic Self-care Nutrition Method on the Lipid Profile of Patients with Type 2 Diabetes: A Randomized Clinical Controlled Trial. Open Access Macedonian Journal of Medical Sciences, 2020,8(B). (Open Access Macedonian Journal of Medical Sciences - http://www.id-press.eu/mjms/). The publisher for Open Access Macedonian Journal of Medical Sciences is ID Design 2012/DOOEL Skopje.

A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3889/oamjms.2020.4217.

Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Manizheh Zakizad Abkenar, Department of Community Health Nursing, Nasibeh School of Nursing and Midwifery, Mazandaran University of Medical Sciences, Sari, Iran. Additional authors for this research include Fazlollah Ghofranipour, Zahra Kashi, Ali Montazeri.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
